summary: A graphic novelist (John Cusack) begins a desperate search for his estranged wife (Clark Sarullo) and son (Ethan Andrew Casto) after a mysterious cellphone signal transforms New Englanders into savage killers.

reviews.content: My only question is why didn't they take a vehicle ?

The critics hate it. The neophyte critics think it fair to good. I'm with the newbies. The  movie starts with a bang. People run amok. And the result is a good bit of mayhem. Most of the horror is well done. The camera is often too close to the characters but things improve as the film progresses. 

I'm only half way through so don't take this as a final rating. Cusack and Jackson are fine. Nothing more nothing less. I say watch it till you fall asleep or get bored or __________ (that space is up to you).
I thought this was a good take. On the zombie genre, could of done more but it's a good watch

It wasn't bad.  It had a unique angle on the zombie genre that I think made others rating the movie uncomfortable.  I'd say the low rating of this movie is more related to how many people who didn't think they would survive instead of the quality of the movie.

Samuel L. Jackson always puts on a good show. You can see him almost wincing throughout this movie, probably because he knows how bad it is. Basically, some signal from cell phones turn people into a violent hive mind that kills off everyone not under their spell. It is the product of Stephen King, who is hit and miss. When, he is good, he is great, then there is this one. It did pass the time, while I was messing around on my laptop.
Perhaps the crappiest movie to ever be released... ever!

Very poor, despite the presence of John Cusack and Samuel L. Jackson.

'Cell' is basically 'Land of the Dead' without the proper zombies, at least that's what this 2016 flick kept reminding me of. That George A. Romero film is good, this Tod Williams release is not. It's a mess throughout and lacks any tension, freshness or uniqueness.

Cusack and Jackson should be a good pairing, yet I don't even recall anything from their respective performances just minutes after watching. Both are capable of a lot better than this, especially Jackson. No-one sticks out behind that duo, though it's neat to see 'Prison Break' actor Stacy Keach involved.

One to avoid, I'd say.
Cell goes from being unintentionally hilarious to painfully boring

I figured I would get both Stephen King adaptations starring Jackson and Cusack in today once I had already watched 1408 early this morning. I had no idea this was going to essentially be a zombie movie and should have been able to see the blatant metaphor coming with the cell phone effects mentioned in the synopsis.

It usually isn't a good sign when you see a bunch of totally unfamiliar production companies popping up in the opening credits, my favorite in this case being The Genre Company. This was pretty low budget and started losing my attention after a while but I actually didn't mind the ending which kept this from the dreaded 1* or lower.

Samuel L. Jackson Binge: Samuel L. Jackson actually wasn't bad here
... or in this case may have just looked better against the backdrop of such a lousy movie and another actor I don't particularly care for.

SLJ January #42

Wastes no time kicking into gear, but runs out of steam just as fast. Marred by unnecessarily erratic camera work, cheap VFX, a dozy script, lousy editing, & a terrible ending, it adds little to an already overly-polluted zombie genre. #nitrosMovieChallenge

Wow i have never seen a movie with less than a 20% on RT that turned out to be good until CELL. Not sure why people hate it!!! Its prob because Cusack is never really likable, always comes off as a dlck. Or maybe because Sam Jackson doesnt say MuthaF&$@& not even once and that was disappointing actually. But i watched this late and alone and i think it built alot of tension had a few good jump scares and was unsettling. The ending gets lots of bad press too and idk why. there are enough clues to know what happened and its dark. I would have liked to see a snip of what Tom and the chic and kid ended up doing but oh well maybe ill read the book now since i heard its way bettwr than the movie and maybe it will give their ending. Anyway if u like horror movies give it a shot. I did and i enjoyed it quite a bit. - darkhao
Such a great book 2 actors I think are great and 1 terrible movie

Stephen King's 2006 novel gets a screen adaptation via a low budget and some really poor CGI. Samuel L. Jackson continues on his path to be in every film EVER, but the real tragedy is seeing how the great John Cusack has become such a bargain bin actor. What the hell happened?
Terrible movie. A complete waste of time.
Terrible movie. I wish I had seen the reviews first. It makes no sense and is a totally disjointed plot. One scene does not lead into another. Great actors with a terrible Director!!! Sont bother

I’m of two minds on Cell. It doesn’t come close to living up to the novel, but if wikipedia is to be believed it was shot for 1 million dollars. There is just no way to convey the epic scale of the novel on such limited resources. To that extent Cell is a business faiure not so much a storytelling failure. Tod Williams did the very best he could under the circumstances and arguably he delivered more than could be reasonably expected.
I wish I could give no stars. Possibly the worst film I watched. Avoid

this was fine; the only difference between this & other zombie films is HOW they become zombies i guess. otherwise there's really not a whole lot of originality to the story. i do, however, like tragic endings in general, so i enjoyed this one's.
Despite a solid lead from its two supporting cast, Cell at times shows glimpses of a capable thriller movie. But ends In a disappointing fashion.

I completely missed when this came out. Four years ago? Really? And Samuel L. Jackson just stars in anything that gets offered to him, apparently. He is A-List, and this was during MCU's glory days. He doesn't even need the money. Why does he say yes to every single role? As far as zombie survival flicks, this ranks pretty low. It just jumps right into it, and the zombies' behavior keeps changing, so there weren't any fun rules of engagement to keep you on edge. Just a lot of running and shooting and blowing things up. Not a lot of meat to give it some much needed complexity.

An interesting film, that begins with anyone on a mobile or electronic device is hit with some noise that renders them into some sort of trance They then turn on anyone who is not infected or affected.
A group of survivors then try to make their way across the country but the power of the people infected are able to follow them if one sees through their eyes they all do!
The signals from the phone masts are what controls them and at night the people sleep with the phones giving them messages.
The story is good, but some of it makes no sense, the man blowing himself up, and the ending ruin the film
Don't waste your time on this movie. Just plain rotten.
Classic Stephen King. A few scary parts that make you wonder, but otherwise predictable. Even the twist at the end was expected.
Just plain awful. These actors must have been desperate to be part of this movie.
Don't waste your time with this movie.
Surprised Samuel L Jackson would agree to do a movie this awful.

I completely disagree with all the negative reviews! I thought this movie was compelling and held my attention throughout. The subject matter is deeply disturbing, as it's meant to be, and it's well acted by all. John Cusack and Samuel L. Jackson are great, as always, and the supporting actors and actresses are equally strong. This is a zombie movie with a contemporary twist, as only Stephen King could twist it, and in this age of COVID doesn't even seem that implausible. Will humanity be zombified by cell phones...or vaccines? Stay tuned. And, in the meantime, don't miss this dark apocalyptic thriller. PS: That opening scene? In the airport? The stuff of nightmares.

Appalling! Character development is non-existent the whole way through. Acting is not convincing at all. The Director must have been asleep! A massive shame, when you take a look at the two main players

The worst low budget, bad cgi, badly acted and 
written movie I've seen in ages. John Cusack 
was a boring, same lazy character, acting as 
himself. as usual. WASTE OF TIME!
I really well played cast. It is not really a Horror and a thriller movie. It is a cell phone sickness it can cause them crazy and killing them self's
Taking one of King's worst books and dumbing it down, this film is a big dumb zombie film with undeveloped characters.

I finally have one - a movie I like that no one else does.   

I came across this a few months back, late night on the SyFy.  The critics and audience scores were so abysmal I had to check it out because it didn't sound that bad.  I didn't think it was that bad even with commercials, so I decided to view it again - this time unedited and commercial free.  I will say this much, I am not a cell phone user so that may be why I feel this is horribly underrated.  I suppose zombie movies and shows like The Walking Dead are cool until it's screaming right inside your ear and head. I'm apparently against the masses on this one. 

3 1/2 of 5
Just remember all those people talking about Bill Gates and 5g conspiracy theoris gave this movie five stars and were scared by it :)

Don't waste your time.
The writing was just terrible..
Overly dramatic lines.

The plot of our cellphones essentially brainwashing people into insanity, is just ridiculous.

Given the popularity of Zombie movies in the last 10+ years, here's another one to attempt to get your attention.

Here's an example of the idiotic writing in this movie: 2 or 3 of the travellers continue to keep their phones powered on, after knowing full well, that the phones are used to transmit the brainwashing music/sound.  Only after a few days, do they decide to dump them.

It's based on a Stephen King novel, so the "twist" ending was totally predictable. That said, I enjoyed watching the movie for the interesting premise, the end-of-the-world aspect, and the mystery. It doesn't deserve the low RT rating.
These two are way to good for this.

this film tries to be serious but fails quite resoundingly in most scenes. Meanwhile nothing is explained and this thing instead of giving a sense of mystery alone a feeling of incompleteness, then no character is properly thorough and the ending is stupid and useless

To think of the movies these two have made and they sign up for this tripe ?! Why did John put his hat on in the mayhem at the airport ? Did they realise that his hair looked like the wig that it was ? Abominable in all the wrong ways.

I remember reading the Stephen King novel when  it came out,  but if I recall correctly, I didn't finish it because it was so over-written, like a lot of his work. Still, it had an interesting premise.
This film has a vague premise that's never really explained. It's also ridiculously bad--shoddy production values, actors trying to keep a straight face with the knowledge of what a rotten movie they're in, uninteresting cinematography. Every aspect is just flat out BAD. Like a third rate Invasion of the Body Snatchers. 

It seems that King film adaptations are either really excellent (Shawshank, The Green Mile), or total disasters. I can't imagine why.

Cell has a good plot, but the development could been so much better. There are some pretty scenese, but really, nothing more. The characters behave dumb or cliché and they really not in-depth. There aren't narratives ideas that surprise the viewer, or at least, those what are in there, leaves us indifferent. The presence of this dude with the red hoodie which should represents a kind of leader of all the phone zombies, it's not so logic, as well as the fact that it has the same appearance as the protagonist of Clay's graphic novel (as if the latter must somehow be the chosen one, or that in some way he predicted the future. This thing is thrown there like this, and it doesn't the flap is made clear), and that then everybody continue to have nightmares on him. Even the ending it's unclear and scratching (SPOILER), first of all we see Clay, his son and the rest of the zombies exploding, then they show us a kind of dreamalike scene, where we see father and son in their way to the others survivors, and in the next scene we see again the horde running in circle, with clay inside of it too, who's somehow he's an infected now. All of this group of scenes it seemed very unconvincing to me, i can't find the real logic of it. Among other flaws, it's worthless speaking of the special effects, which between fire and explosions, they're often poorly made.

Another King film with a bad ending. Don't know if it's just his movies but King just can't get a quality ending to his stories. Decent movie but vague BS for a finish. I fell for it again.
 Did no one mention the ties to The Kingsman movie? In The Kingsman, Sam Jackson plays an evil mastermind with a plan to make people violently crazy, through a cell phone signal. In Cell, Sam Jackson tries to survive the exact same concept... Coincidence? 
Kingsman was a MUCH better movie.

Stephen King was on screenplay duties so of course the film had an extended run time that deserved an intermission. This aside, this post-apoclayptic flick is worth a watch just for the gory intro and the convincable suspense interwoven through the picture. Plus John Cusack plays a comic book artist? Love for the culture!
Yeah, the ending was a little rushed as, but if that pace for the final moments would have been induced in the more slower scenes in this film (and if some of the explosions weren't so low budget) - this would have been perfect. Though despite the small mistakes, Cell is another example that Stephen King film adaptations that were released during the 2010's are more entertaining than any King stories that made it from script to screen in the past - yes and that includes the snorefest that was The Shining, R.I.P. Kubrick.
Horrible adaptation of a good Book. The Ending made it even worse. S. Jackson can´t save this trainwreck of a Movie
This movie was creepy in the sense that if cell phone towers could be hacked and a signal sent out like that....what if?
It's amateurish at spots but it has great actors and some good zombie sequences
watched this... horrible horrible.... horrible mistake... now I want my wasted time back so I can waste it somewhere else. its so bad I wish I could just unwatch it or forget completely about it.

Rotten tomatoes can fuck them selves and their mothers. Cell is a great movie with a very unique way of showing horror mixed with the apocalypse as well as having a different type of zombie film we never seen before.  The zombies are not just a horde of zombies but a family of zombies that works in unique ways with one of them being telepathic.

Weird movie. The story makes absolutely no sense and the acting is just plain bad. I was confused about everything from the zombies to the apocalypse and the entire cell phone concept. I'm not sure what the movie was hoping to achieve but it definitely didn't get there as Cell is a terrible waste of time.
I'm a sucker for zombie movies and Stephen King, but this was just OK.  Good concept.

From the standpoint of contemporary zombie movies, as ubiquitous "action flick", it's certainly a good watch.  Approaching it as another story within the "zombie movie/TV universe it's a solid installment.

However...

I think George Romero would have appreciated the contemporary metaphor, warts and all. It's seemingly heavy handed, no doubt; the flaws and tropes are certainly there if one chooses go looking for them. Nevertheless, it does speak to contemporary concerns (to state those concerns would be to give the whole thing away) in the same way that Romero's movies spoke to the concerns of his day.

I don't have to expect the same level of subtle social commentary George Romero imbued his zombie movies with. That's just not fair. I do respect this valiant and, yes, successful homage to his legacy, though.

Stephen King's screenplay appears to be a valiant homage to George Romero's legacy and worthy of a screening.
As a movie the acting is kinda bland and weird, not really sure how to describe it. But if you like zombie movies you should watch this.

It's Slither without a soul.  What a waste of a great cast, and the 2 male leads basically phoned (get it....) their performances in.  Character development stopped after about 10 minutes and new characters were introduced only so there were more people to kill.

Action scenes littered with quick cuts, and washed out colors just made this movie a chore to get through.

Other than the first 10 minutes, which to be honest was well shot and seemed interesting, this movie was a mess and the visual representation of a fart in church.

Big pass on this one.

Poorly shot, indifferently staged, badly written and lacking of coherent scares or respect to its novel counterpart. Cell is one of the worst Stephen King adaptations to date and also acts as a true example on how you should not adapt a book that is written so well but poorly translated for the big screen. The story follows comic book artist Clay who is on his way to meet up with his son after landing a successful deal with his publishers on the latest graphic novel series he's working on. However, terror strikes when people start turning into mindless zombies by answering their cellphones, along the way he meets up with Tom McCourt, Alice Maxwell and computer genius Jordan. Together, they travel across the desolated US as the human population slowly decreases while also unraveling the mysteries of the pulse that turns everyone into zombies. Compared to the newly successful Stephen King adaptations in 2017 like the terrifying IT, Gerald's Game and 1922. Cell is the adaptation that alienated Stephen King fanatics and is a plague in the history of Hollywood movies. This is the film that is doomed from beginning to end and I'm not kidding about that; I read the book it was based on and from the moment the film flows after a decent opening sequence, Cell starts to go downhill as it suffers from a number of setbacks that are inferior to the books powerful moments. The problem with this adaptation is that the new elements incorporated into the film lacks the greatness of the book and adds more plot holes and unanswered questions. Its clear that things went South real fast during the middle of the film as the lack of character development is purely absent by the time the film abruptly ends. The directing is awkward, shoddy and bland that sets new directions in the history of bad film making, nearly every element used are just recycled junk from past movies. The way the film was shot is so bad it made my eyes hurt (Rapid use of cuts, excessive zooming scenes, laughable zombie sound effects and lazy camera work as if it was shot on a plastered handheld video camera filled with poor lighting that makes you think the budget for the film has been reduced for the next half of the film) and finally, the changes from the book is purely absurd that wasted the efforts of everyone involved during pre-production on the film plus the zombies are just as lame as the movie itself. The only two positive things about this film are a few nicely shot scenes during the apocalypse at the airport (one where Clay sees people acting odd after answering their cellphones including a violent death during the subway sequence) and the casting of the film is good from John Cusack, Samuel L. Jackson, Isabelle Fuhrman too Owen Teague as Clay Riddell, Tom McCourt, Alice Maxwell and Jordan respectively but these four deserve to be in better movies than in this film for good reason. Director Tod Williams is one of the worst Horror directors of all time as he shows how much of a huge hack he is in the genre when he made both Paranormal Activity 2 and this film. His work in the first Paranormal Activity sequel is ok but slightly better than what he did here as he butchered Stephen King's incredible story into a crumbling magnitude that sinks faster than a quicksand and shows that these type of films should be handed to those who admire the work of Horror Maestro Stephen King. Cell overall is one of the worst adaptations of a Stephen King novel that is easily forgettable and leaves a bad taste in your mouth. This is one of the worst zombie films of all time. I am giving this movie a 2/10.
Worst adaptation ever awesome book horrible movie. This movie actually made me angry at how bad it was.

The first 15 minutes of this movie was really strong.  It gripped me and I thought I was going to be in for a good movie!  However, it kind of falls apart more and more as it goes on.  By the time I got to the end of it, I just felt like I was sucker punched.  There may be a few guilty moments of entertainment in this one, but I can't say that it is a good movie.
The story was didn't flow well and this was overall not enjoyable.

I actually liked the movie! I guess the dialogue was kinda weird at the beginning, at lear for me (I watched in in my lenguage so I don't know how it is on the Original version), the acting is pretty good at some points, I feeled the plot was also kinda fast and  the main message of the movie got lost, but for me, it was enjoyable.
While it gets to the blood and guts (with which there is plenty) in no time, this movie is utterly devoid of any discernible plot
This was unfortunately not very good.

Having read and loved the book, I looked forward to seeing this.   It's 2018 and I just found out this movie existed.  If I ever get cancer, I blame this abomination.  Samuel L. knew it was terrible too.  His acting was devoid of any emotion.  The book had amazing character development.  This movie had none, and I felt no emotion towards the characters at all.  While the ending of the book was a bit confusing, it left the future up to the reader's imagination.  The movie ending was totally confusing.  The Phoners were far more than zombies.  This film didn't care.  It was "Night Of The Living Living."  Fetid trash.  I'd rather die than ever see this again.

If there were a negative number I would choose that. Horrible movie, terrible script that didn't go by the book even though Steven King wrote it himself, underdeveloped characters that had no complete story and had Key dialogue that was never actually realized or going anywhere, a waste of great cast and an ending that made no sense even for a cliffhanger type of film. It was a waste of two hours of my life. I could nitpick almost every scene in it. I should have known it was going to be bad when Samuel L Jackson never said one "mother f'er" in his dialogue.

There was a time when the Dracula movies were the rage. Now we are in a zombie movie period. This zombie one reminds the 70s film Invasion of the body snatchers. Today, we don't waste time on details in movies, we go right to the gruesome. In any case, this was a not so new take. Too psychopathic and a bit ridiculous in how cruel zombies and anti-zombies are. Felt like english vs indians. Good last line though: "we're going to Canada". But please, don't come here!
Decent, until the ending...
Story kind of sucks, but they did a good job on every other part of the movie.
It wasn't a novel but a short story.  The beginning or ending was not that of the book but was scary none the less.

It was a horrible movie to a really bad book (I'm sorry Steph, you know I'm a huge fan anyways). I started and couldn't finish it at my first try and I even forgot that it existed. I finaly finished this hard task of watching this nonsense of a movie.

Too little, too late! NGL it does have some pretty good chills, nice bit of acting between the two leads and a terrifically gruesome and funny scene with the always great Stacy Keach, a flaming arrow, a gas truck and a soccer stadium full of sleeping zombies or  "phoners" as they're called. But ultimately it's all just very mediocre and not very scary or suspenseful. John Cusack and Samuel L. Jackson, it should be noted are fine here, despite others saying they're uh, phoning it in..but their first Stephen King adapted feature together was phenomenally better ('1408'). If you're a Stephen King fan, love horror but for some reason have not seen that yet, please check it out before this mess. You'll thank me later.
Being an avid multiple times Stephen King book reader ? IT'S the sams S.Different Day movie fails to capture the King thoughts/written word transformation onto the Silver Bul....Screen!!!!
Certainly was a creepy story. Did you ever get that feeling that the whole world has turned into cell phone zombies?Take away the cell phone towers & they'd all jusst drop dead in their place?

I may not have read the book, but I can tell this is easily one of the worst Stephen King adaptions I have ever seen. The premise is displayed to be completely ridiculous, and makes it seem like poor acting is now a disease. Not a single interaction between Cusack and Jackson was the slightest bit interesting, and never once shifted the tones of their voices from the bland, dull, usual tone we got in this movie.

Samuel L Jackson, previously one of Hollywood's most wanted actors, has dropped to a new low with this bomb of a film. If anyone could make this movie less bland and predictable, it would be Samuel. Unfortunately, not even he could save this movie from the eternal hell of forgettable movies.

This movie got so painful to watch that I couldn't handle listening to Cusack's monotone voice any longer. If you asked me what happened after the first half of the movie, I honestly couldn't give you a decent answer. With the combination of lousy dialogue and shoddy acting, it was just too boring to watch.

Overall, 2/10 for in my opinion, the years worst movie.

I don't get it all the bad reviews I found Cell to be a different and much more intertaining look at the zombie films we've all grown accustomed to I thought Cell was an above average movie if ur tired of the same old rehash give Cell a look you might be surprised

A graphic novelist (John Cusack) begins a desperate search for his estranged wife (Clark Sarullo) and son (Ethan Andrew Casto) after a mysterious cellphone signal transforms New Englanders into savage killers.

Started off well, but the second half and ending was disappointing.
ABSOLUTELY AWFUL AND I WISH I COULD GET THE TIME I SPENT WATCHING BACK. ID RATHER SIT ON THE TOILET WHILE BEING CONSTIPATED!!!!!!!!!!??
Boring and uninspired. Lacks any of the flavors and subtleties of Mr King's work. From a production value point of view the closing scenes were so DARK it was impossible to see what was going on.

Maybe it's first minutes are genuinely solid, at least for a zombie-infected flick, but truth is, once the actual plot rockets the movie falls, little by little, into not just a conventionalist-stereotypical B-movie, but the presence of both, John Cusack and Samuel L. Jackson is tremendously wasted, and even Stephen King's writing couldn't do much for this poorly executed and flat looking film, that couldn't live up to other adaptations quality.

Although an interesting plot of cellular-induced mania and a world gone apocalyptic, the return of Cusak and Jackson in another King adaptation is not worth its wait since Room 1408 (2007). The ending will bring you a finale that will not bring sympathy.

Just the worst... Every thing is the worst in this movie, its a extremely low-budget. Bad acting, bad script, laughable soundtrack. It was a hour thirty, it felt like a three hour movie.  If I could give it a zero I would have.

It was slightly better than what the reviews have rated it but in the end it was not very good. I am biased as a zombie fan but this was not really a zombie film. If it was it would be in the bottom tier of the worst ones. Half way through I thought it was going to be ok but as it went on and the ending made the movie just flat bad really. Still worth a watch if you like zombie movies... I guess.

What is truly disheartening is the lack of wonder and thrills that are aplenty in the book. Here is an adaptation that knows it's on its way to failure, yet does nothing to save itself from trash. Worse, it doesn't even try to be decent for its usually appealing leads and clever concept.
After watching 1408 and this, I'm strongly considering not watching any more Stephen King adaptations starring John Cusack and Samuel L. Jackson
Time I will never get back.
Uhm, just rubbish, i switched it off.

I found it to be good movie. Peope kill me with reading a 200 page story and expect it to be in a full movie. If you a real novel reader, Like Me you will know the movieis based of a book but not like the book. So get real and enjoy the movie or go read another novel.

Really actually quite good. Poor CGI, but that's not a killer for me, and a solid ending. I loved the book. the movie sucked
I'm being generous with two stars, only because I actually jumped, fists ready, at what was really the only good scare in the whole movie.

XD HA HA HA. What was this?! I cannot call this a guilty pleasure movie but man was I laughing. Its horrendously crafted. Horribly directed, terrible editing, the plot is laughable, lacks any suspense. Its bad people, its really, really bad.

Cell doesn't even come close to the 'so bad it's good' category. It's just bad. Really bad. Even Stephen King and zombie fans will want to stay clear. I haven't read the book, but I am confident this is not a stellar translation. A shame to see Jackson and Cusack wasted on such an amateur production. Don't even rent.

As a zombie movie this was good enough to watch all the way through and it had decent elements of a thriller story line going on that keep the viewers attention. However the ending is such a bad jump the shark moment it renders everything before  it to be completely pointless and a waste of time. Very poorly written movie that disguises itself as a good movie for a long period of time.
I would give this film no stars, but don't seem to able to.  Lots of jump scares, good set up, but no pay off.  Too much left unexplained and very unsatisfied.
Just plain boring and an incomprehensible ending that is NOT in the book.
Pretty pointless and deserved better even if the book wasn't the greatest in the first place, but captures the mood well.

Holy piece-of-crap Batman! While I will admit that there were MOMENTS that this movie was "ok", they were far and few in between. Throughout the entire film I kept waiting for questions to be answered, and they weren't. And the ending!... what the heck was that? Just disappointing.
It's such a shame to see Samuel L Jackson be demoted to such horrible movie... Is his career over? Do not watch.
Goes on the list with Dreamcatcher as one of the worst Stephen King adaptations. No one in this film seems to care at all about the movie...

The cast look bored, the script is woeful, the pacing is all over the place, the production is laughably bad with the CGI being on par with something from SyFy, the plot is boring and cumbersome and the score is forgettable.
Ugh. This movie is so deeply bad, and the ending just makes no sense. I had good expectation for this one, specially because of the formidable cast, but now I am just sad.
It's not the greatest but it's better than this overall score! Some very interesting/freaky visuals and I liked the ending.
I can't believe this is actually a real movie!
That movie was so bad

complete garbage, should have known as soon as i saw sam's name on the box.  To be more specific, horrible character development, i really dont care about any of them, the whole premise is dumb, and really...., a dream sequence with a zombie blowing himself with a severed head? Not a good movie to watch

I wouldn't even waste my time with the preview. I don't understand how or why a movie like this would be made. Read the script throw it away. Can't someone write a decent movie to spend money filming? Snakes on a plane. Where do they come up with this stuff? John Cusac, Nicolas Cage, Steven Segal and Tom Cruise need to retire!

It kept me interested without being overly disgusting. It showed what our society is turning into a bit exaggerated but not inconceivable. Yet I still wanted to know who (if) there was someone was behind this apocalypse. The ending was hopeful at first the last scene brought back the doom

This probably would've been great a few years ago and with better CGI / a bigger budget, but instead it just feels like an already used up idea being used again hoping that Stephen King's name would be enough to save it. Well, it wasn't enough to save it, but the ending is pretty great and there is some okay zombie fun to be had here.

Review:
When I saw that this was a Samuel L. Jackson movie, which didn't even make a million dollars at the box office, I knew that it must have been terrible, and now that I've watched it, I can totally understand why. As soon as the zombie activity started at the beginning of the film, I fell asleep and I lost complete interest in the plot. I struggled to keep my eyes open through the rest of the movie, and I personally think that it was a terrible and cheaply made. John Cusack plays a graphic novel creator, Clay Riddell, who is on his way home from selling some of his work. At the airport, he calls his family on his cell phone but his battery runs out, so he heads to the phone box and witnesses people becoming extremely violent whilst foaming at the mouth and killing each other. After escaping the strange goings on in the airport, he realises that there strange behaviour is something to do with there cell phones, hence the title of the film, and he eventually hooks up with a train driver, Tom McCourt (Samuel L. Jackson), who helps Clay to get home to his loved ones. On there journey, Clays neighbour, Alice Maxwell (Isabelle Fuhrman) joins them to get to safety but as the Pulse starts to take over humanity, nowhere is safe. I'm not one for zombie movies, so I really wasn't interested in that aspect of the movie but I thought there would be other elements which could have been entertaining. How wrong was I! The acting was pretty poor from these top actors, because I didn't get a sense of intensity or shock throughout the movie. It also seemed like the zombies were just a bunch of extras with make-up on there face, so there wasn't a sense of reality or horror. Some of the graphic scenes at the airport were pretty shocking but apart from that, it really wasn't anything amazing. The whole concept about people catching a bug from using the phone, was great, which is why my expectations were quite high but the director really didn't take full advantage of the cast and Stephen Kings original story. Disappointing!

Round-Up:
With such a massive career, which has earned him millions of dollars, Samuel L. Jackson is allowed to make some poor movies from time to time. The sad thing is Cusack and Jackson did try and make the crazy Pulse situation seem realistic, which must have been hard because it did seem quite ridiculous most of the time. Anyway, the film was directed by Tod Williams, 48, who also brought you the Adventures of Sebastian Cole, The Door In The Floor and Paranormal Activity 2. Taking on a Stephen King novel, must have been a big task for this director, who really done a terrible job adapting the book for the big screen. Movies like I Am Legend, proves that it is possible to pull off a zombie movie without constantly running around with guns trying to fight them off, so maybe they should redo this film with a director who could bring depth and reality to the project.

Worldwide Gross: $735,000

I recommend this movie to people who are into their horror/sci-fi/thrillers, starring John Cusack, Samuel L. Jackson, Stacy Keach, Isabelle Fuhrman, Joshua Mikel and Clark Sarullo. 2/10

Over the many year's movies have existed there's been a large number of questions raised by movies with answers non-forthcoming. These are questions that have been at the forefront of many a coffee date discussion, movie club forum or family dinner. Questions like who exactly is/was the "thing" (The Thing), is it a dream or reality (Inception), what was in the briefcase (Pulp Fiction) and now with this long completed and finally just released Stephen King adaptation we can add why exactly was John Cusack's in danger graphic novelist Clay Riddell so keen to pop on his beanie in the midst of a do or die cell phone lead apocalypse?

It's a question we may sadly never have answered and probably the only thing that will stick with you once Tod William's (where has the director who made The Door in the Floor gone?) film reaches its credit sequence, as this adaptation of one of King's least regarded books is one of those films just waiting to join the likes of The Wicker Man remake as a film that's just so bizarre and random it's hard to know who did and why they decided this was a film the public wanted.

In all its random glory however, if I was being totally honest, after all the negative press and jokes being made at its expense, Cell is not nearly as bad as it could've been when watched with the right mindset.

A seriously daft idea that induces a large amount of unintended laughter, Cell has its fair share of "what the" moments and it's a little sad seeing the likes of John Cusack (although he seems to have sold his movie soul some time ago now) and Samuel L. Jackson act through some insanely bizarre situations; I truly can't even begin to explain a scene involving a field of sleeping cell phone zombies, the film actually has some decent scenes and ideas that make this a B grade experience you can sit back and laugh at or with and an experience best watched with a room full of friends all up to witness a film that should never have made it to the cold light of day.

Through the history of movies we've been treated to King adaptation gold, from experiences like The Shawshank Redemption, The Green Mile, The Shining and The Mist, Cell is certainly not one of those and is certainly not a film of cinematic virtue but it's an experience that deserves to be seen as even if you hate every minute of this oddball ride its likely you've never seen anything like it before and if you solve the beanie mystery, please let me know.

After finding one that Cell, one of my favorite Stephen King books, had been released nearly under the radar as a film I was eager to see it. Sadly however this doesn't come close to what the book offered.

The film follows Clay, a artist, who after realizing that a weird cell phone signal has sent the world into a crazed apocalyptic state he is determined to travel back to New England to get his son. Along the way he meets other survivors along the rest in his quest for his son.

Now for a film starring John Cusack (who also co-produced it), Samuel L Jackson and Isabelle Furhman all the actors just look like they are phoning it in. Cusack and Jackson almost always have a bland emotionless look on there face making it clearly apparent that there wasn't a strong love for this film by them. It doesn't help either that the film has such a hard time grabbing you in. I never sensed any danger for the characters or truly even cared as there wasn't much backstory given for anyone to make me care about them.

The worst thing is that even with knowledge of the book I was still confused because they often failed to give full explanations for things in the film leaving a casual viewer likely confused. I can imagine if I was confused as to what was going on then almost anyone else would be even more lost. By the end however knowing that they fully changed the ending was even worse, the end is a total letdown for the film and just feels almost like a cheap cop out.

From the beginning scene in the airport though they set your hopes so high, the beginning is tense and violent and starts with a rush only to slow down too much. Even with the occasional good moment from the infected in the film the constant horrible CGI really dumbs it down.

Overall with this letdown of a film just read the book instead.

Cell is a surprisingly good zombie movie that blends in some sci fi and takes advantage of the fact that the genre has been well-explored recently by trimming away most of the fat and giving fans what they want. Which is not to say the film is non-stop, senseless violence, but it doesn't waste much time explaining itself. The last third could have even been longer, but Cell still accomplishes its goals, with just the right amount of absurdity, humor, violence, emotion, and social commentary true fans have come to expect from zombie films. It doesn't exactly break new ground, but watching Cusack and Jackson navigate their way through the apocalypse is more than enough to satisfy.

In Stephen King's On Writing, the author talks about how interesting situations to push your characters into can be expressed with a single "what if?" question. Tod Williams follows that great advice in this adaptation on multiple occasions: What if the film's antagonist (the Raggedy Man) were significantly less threatening and creepy than he was in the book? Constant Readers who have been waiting for this film for almost a decade will leave disappointed and angry, and casual viewers will roll their eyes at the film's shallow social criticism.

I have been a huge Stephen King fan from the time I have, well,  started reading. So its been natural for me to check out almost every film adaptions of his novels. While I do understand that novel adaptions are usually very hit or miss (except for YA I presume) as its much harder to please those who haven't read the text before. Nevertheless As a true King fan, I have even come to support some of his failed adaptions such as Dreamcatcher, Secret Window (the remake), The Mist etc, hence you can understand my excitement for this one. The concept of this film based on King's lesser successful novels seemed interesting, especially in today's world where our reliance on our cell phones has reached sky's limit (putting it lightly). Plus the re pairing of actors John Cusack & Samuel L Jackson after King's widely overlooked yet awesome 1408, seemed like a great idea. So how is this film? Pretty terrible! Yup, this is not a good movie. If there was anything I could compare it to, it would be director M.Night Shyamalan's The Happening (except slightly less idiotic). Everything about the movie was just wrong and I honestly gave it a lot of room, a lot of space to make errors and not flow the same. Because ultimately you want to be surprised by the movie. You ultimately want the director to make it his own just a little bit, put his spin on something and have it shine even more. And I did, I watched the film to the very end. Checked behind the credits and everything. And now I wish I would have gone on for the rest of my life without knowing this movie existed. Instead of cleverly using the plot, the makers decided to just rip off the very popular TV series The Walking Dead for a 98 minute film. While The Walking Dead is produced as a character-driven thrill ride whereas this film decided to be nothing but a low budget borefest. The story follows Clay Riddell (John Cusack), a comic book artist estranged from his family who arrives at the Boston airport and is traveling home when all of a sudden, some sort of signal scrambles the brains of everyone currently using a cellphone. Most of them immediately turn into mindless, murderous zombies in a bit of staged mayhem that does not convince, unfortunately. Clay runs for his life. He meets up with random fellow survivors - the train conductor Tom McCourt (Samuel L. Jackson) and the teenage neighbor Alice (Isabelle Fuhrman). Together, they form the vague notion to travel north into New Hampshire. Clay wants to find his young son. But the roads are thick with "phoners," who are beginning to manifest new abilities that suggest the development of a psychic hive mind. At first I felt the opening shots of this film set the tone for its overall success. They hold and pan shakily over the airport bustle as blocky opening credits cover most of the frame. It is hard to see anything in this visual climate, but what we do see is an airport in which literally every person has their phone in their hands. I mean, does nobody read books at the airport anymore? Do people actually talk on their phones at the urinal? Once the dust settles, Clay is in denial. Having just gotten off the phone with his estranged wife, and later texting her to a response of absolute gibberish, his wife is likely zombified ). Clay, ignoring these signs, decides to go out in search for his wife and son instead of staying in his apartment where he is objectively safe. Even though I am sure the opening setting of an airport on paper seems like a great idea especially to gather a multitude of cellphone users who end up as victims of the so-called pulse. The result is a collection of sometimes hallucinatory images. Such as the security guard who tears apart his four-legged friend. Or that frenzied teenage girl who runs head-on against a wall, with a toothless, bloody smile as a result. And as icing on the cake there's a destructive plane crash (unfortunately with the use of some lousy-looking special effects). Sadly enough there is not much exciting to see after this beginning. The film looks just like a standard zombie flick afterwards, with some survivors hopping around who are being chased by a horde of frenzied "phoners". The film is also filled with plot holes, where everything which seems important is left unexplained. Who's the man in the red hoodie? Why does he pop-up everywhere? There is some gibberish about what the zombies are and how they get created, but there isn't any payoff - and there doesn't seem to be any rules. How come some people become cell phone zombies and some people don't? They're all hearing the same signal. I can understand if this movie was trying to symbolically represent our modern day society and over-reliance on technology, but it doesn't do that well at all. There are no parallels drawn or even characters that care. They all just chug along with no purpose. Even though the film boasts of some delightfully macabre imagery - like a spray truck driving over a field of unconscious "phoners," spraying them with gasoline, so a character played by Stacy Keach can fire a flaming arrow to burn them all alive (this is an actual thing that happens in this movie). Some of these moments are bright spots in a film that desperately needed them. But they're few and far between. That's a lot of plot for a silly zombie movie, and the film grows too bogged down by it, particularly as our protagonists start to report seeing the same antagonistic figure in their dreams (a common King trope). This all goes nowhere, and it doesn't feel that fast. There are scenes in the film where the characters seem to be very close to each other, and have a strong bond with each other but the film moves at such an accelerated pace even someone just casually watching this would struggle to find the close relationships plausible as none of the people portrayed have had long enough to get to know each other. This would have been a lot better if the characters were actually interesting, but there are no redeeming qualities about any of them. They're as exciting as a cardboard, with even duller personalities. The narrative drags so hard in the second act that it is easy to ignore their performances. It is easy to ignore much of what is going on, as a matter of fact. By the time we start approaching the climax, all we can hope for is an ending. We get there, eventually, but not before being subjected to a very tepid climax that attempts to achieve multiple things while succeeding at none. Couple everything with uninspired direction by Tod Williams (Paranormal Activity 2) all around and some unconvincing performances, and you have something of a trial to get through. During the entire length of the movie, I couldn't help but keep asking "What happened to John Cusack??". Now Samuel L Jackson makes his share of schlocky B-movies, but he also makes some good ones in between. Lately it seems that John Cusack has taken the Nicolas Cage route of becoming insignificant in cinema. Where Cusack used to make memorable and crowd-pleasing movies, his catalog of recent movies have been average at best - and unwatchable at worst. Here, he seems to be chugging along and speaking all his lines in a low raspy voice, I guess to seem more dramatic - but his lines have no significance, so it's the opposite of dramatic, just plain boring. Samuel L. Jackson seems to be sleep walking the whole time, while Isabella Fuhrman & Stacy Keach are just fine. On the whole, 'Cell' is both a frustrating & a corny film hereby making it the worst Stephen King adaption I have ever seen.

Disregarding the fact that the two leads in this film are among my most favorite actors, this attempt at the zombie genre fell short, in so much as a zombie flm, but perhaps does hold a redemptive quality for its social significance.
The zombies in CELL are transformed by and forever attached to their phones. The literalness of which, I feel is too simplistic a device to shove in your face throughout  the film, with waning believability as the film progresses to its end. A McGuffin who's impact dies long too early in the plot like a Shyamalan hollow premise, though the performances of both Cusack and Jackson keep you in til the hokey, King end. The two, as well as the entirety of humanity are surely stratified by generation, as we are as a society - the youngest and oldest are least likely to turn, but fall as easy prey to the growing swarm either being torn to shreds or joining the "bad" side.
Of course, where would the film be without another of King's dead ends of the enemy having a face that all the survivors had dreamed about. OOOH OOGA BOOGA. It was surely the story that weakens this film, though admittedly, I have not read the book, and  don't venture towards King as I had long ago.

Keeping it short and sweet I would call this adaptation of a pretty decent Stephen King's novel a dissapointment. From fake looking, mediocre CGI, especially in one of the darkest scenes in the book, the soccer field scene, to a rather weak cast performance, this movie is a letdown almost from the very beginning up to the last scene. The well written characters from the book are nothing more than just carboard cutouts on a poorly animated backdrop. Changing them substantially from their book counterparts also doesn't add any appeal to the film. Actually the changes made to the script are just another nail in this movie's coffin. It's not as much a horror as a thriller with no thrills at all. It has a few moments that are well shot and nicely acted, but it only adds to the overall frustration with the product. It's sad, because with such a great cast and a very good source material, this movie had a lot of potential. A wasted opportunity, as with most of King's adaptations.

Once the film breaks away from its initial conceit, which is to say when Cusack stops reminding people to not use their cell phones, the film becomes a run of the mill zombie movie. Save for the zombies becoming a living embodiment of their phones (and we thought the phones were an extension of us!), where they make inhuman noises that sound like dial-up and power down at night, they are merely zombies. The added elements are flair, and reverse the day-night dynamic of the horror genre, but they are not really interesting.

This angle Cell takes is a thinly veiled metaphor for our dependence on cell phone technology, but that doesnâ??t make the premise worthwhile. As the characters discuss the nature of the disease, trying to crack the code of the phoneâ??s grasp on the phoners, nothing progresses. Given the outlandishly fantastical way of the phonies, the source and reasoning behind them should not be the central interest. The narrative is a travelogue, at its core, which would lend its hand more readily to an exploration of slice-of-life snippets in the survivor landscape. We get plenty of characters along the way but little in the way of travelogue intrigue.

The acting performances from leads Cusack, Samuel L. Jackson, and Isabella Fuhrman are fine, but it means little. The narrative drags so hard in the second act that it is easy to ignore their performances. It is easy to ignore much of what is going on, as a matter of fact. By the time we start approaching the climax, all we can hope for is an ending. We get there, eventually, but not before being subjected to a very tepid climax that attempts to achieve multiple things while succeeding at none.

What do you get with Stephen King's latest science fiction fiction horror that adds a spin twist on cellular devices? A world of people's constant use of cell phones turning them into mindless maniacs. From the opening scene, taking place in a airport and seeing about everyone using there cell phones and at a moment the electronic signal reprograms everyone that is using their phones into maniac killers. Sure, the film does make them look like mindless zombies, as they chase people down, beat them with blunt objects, and walk around the area. Only at night, all the mind-controlled people are synced to walking around the cell towers or collapsed in the middle of the field playing some song. Cell has a mystery aspect to the concept and could have been an entertaining idea. It fails terribly in going any further into details about the apocalyptic madness of mobile networks causing havoc and turning people into mindless maniacs. Stephen King's stories are usually hits and misses and the endings are the judgment calls if it ties well. Cell plays out an apocalyptic survival story of a divorced father Clay (John Cusack) trying to get home to find his family during this crisis. Seeking the help from Tom (Samuel L. Jackson) and his neighbor Alice (Isabelle Fuhrman) as they travel across distance and avoiding the horde of "phoners."  The film could have had a better direction that could have build suspense, characters, and make it entertaining. Except at times, it was slightly boring, as the script gives unnecessary dull character drama. The suspense is only build with characters running from set piece to another being chased by the horde. The interaction between the characters felt unrealistic like Clay and Tom who have just met and looks like they are best friends. The dialogue is atrocious, which could have improved. From the first 10 minutes of the movie, Clay has landed and witness the people around him change in seconds to killers and chaos breaks loose, as planes crash, people killing each other, and everything crumbles quickly. The acting is also cheesy and the transition with the people turning into mindless killers was also weird and felt like the extras were not told much about their performances and reactions. Also, the ending was suppose to be the point of leaving things haunting and unease, but it felt out of place in a terrible direction. Like it was trying to pull off a twist and ends in a dumb haunting feel. The ending needed some work of giving a better cliffhanger closure of the concept and plot, but ends in a cheesy stupid way. Cell is the worst at giving a sharp science fiction direction for a Stephen King story, has a terrible script and direction, and cheesy acting. This King story being adapted into film is a definite miss.
